perturbation.original_text: Within 2 weeks following execution of this Agreement, PlanetCAD will provide Dassault Systemes with the necessary media and licensing keys or similar authorization system (if any) to use such Server Software and Infrastructure according to the above license.
perturbation.changed_text: Within 30 days following execution of this Agreement, PlanetCAD will provide Dassault Systemes with the necessary media and licensing keys or similar authorization system (if any) to use such Server Software and Infrastructure according to the above license.
perturbation.explanation: Extended timeframe for providing media and licensing keys. The original text requires PlanetCAD to provide Dassault Systemes with necessary media and licensing keys within 2 weeks of the agreement's execution. The modified text extends this to 30 days. The change ensures compliance with business timelines, avoiding potential legal issues arising from an overly restrictive deadline.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Reasonableness of Timeframes

perturbation.original_text:
The other party will have 30 days from the reception of such information to accept or refuse such payment/withholding:
     (i)  If the other party accepts or does not answer within this time frame,
          the Billing Party will be entitled to make such payment/withholding
          and shall provide the other party with a certificate stating the
          amounts withheld and the jurisdictions to which such amounts were
          remitted.
     (ii) If the other party provides to the Billing Party a certificate stating
          that (a) the Billing Party has no withholding/payment obligations with
          respect to the laws of such particular jurisdiction and setting forth
          the relevant authority for such statement and/or (b) that such a
          payment may be avoided under any applicable law or treaty and provide
          with the necessary documentation for that purpose, and if the Billing
          Party then determines that it has no such withholding obligation under
          the laws of such jurisdiction, the Billing Party shall make any future
          payments to the other party without deduction for the items set forth
          in the certificate, until such time as the Billing Party reasonably
          believes that it has a withholding obligation.
perturbation.changed_text:
The other party will have 10 days from the reception of such information to accept or refuse such payment/withholding:
     (i)  If the other party accepts or does not answer within this time frame,
          the Billing Party will be entitled to make such payment/withholding
          and shall provide the other party with a certificate stating the
          amounts withheld and the jurisdictions to which such amounts were
          remitted.
     (ii) If the other party provides to the Billing Party a certificate stating
          that (a) the Billing Party has no withholding/payment obligations with
          respect to the laws of such particular jurisdiction and setting forth
          the relevant authority for such statement and/or (b) that such a
          payment may be avoided under any applicable law or treaty and provide
          with the necessary documentation for that purpose, and if the Billing
          Party then determines that it has no such withholding obligation under
          the laws of such jurisdiction, the Billing Party shall make any future
          payments to the other party without deduction for the items set forth
          in the certificate, until such time as the Billing Party reasonably
          believes that it has a withholding obligation.
perturbation.explanation: Reduced timeframe for disputing tax withholdings. This creates an inconsistency by shortening the time the Non-Billing Party has to respond to a request for tax withholding. While there isn't a universal law mandating a specific timeframe, providing only 10 days could be deemed unreasonable and potentially contradict principles of good faith and fair dealing, especially if complex tax laws or international treaties are involved.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: Within 7 Business Days after the end of each calendar quarter, the Billing Party shall provide the other party with an itemized statement, subject to adjustment within 30 days of receipt of such statement, setting forth the Net Revenue achieved over the preceding calendar quarter, and shall include such other information as may be mutually agreed upon by the parties (the "Revenue Report"). The Revenue Report shall be accompanied by payment to the Non-Billing Party of all amounts owed as set forth on such Revenue Report, as well as - when applicable - the exchange currency rate.
perturbation.changed_text: Within 30 Business Days after the end of each calendar quarter, the Billing Party shall provide the other party with an itemized statement, subject to adjustment within 10 days of receipt of such statement, setting forth the Net Revenue achieved over the preceding calendar quarter, and shall include such other information as may be mutually agreed upon by the parties (the "Revenue Report"). The Revenue Report shall be accompanied by payment to the Non-Billing Party of all amounts owed as set forth on such Revenue Report, as well as - when applicable - the exchange currency rate.
perturbation.explanation: Extends the deadline for providing revenue reports while simultaneously shortening the adjustment period. Although not directly conflicting with a specific statute, this combination is unfavorable to the Non-Billing Party and can be regarded as undue burden or violate the implied duty of good faith if the 10-day period is insufficient to review the complex revenue data from the 30 day report.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing
